/kind bug What steps did you take and what happened: [A clear and concise description of what the bug is.] We try to install Kubeflow on the Azure Kubernetes Service (<denchmark-link:https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/kubernetes-service/>https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/kubernetes-service/</denchmark-link> ) clusters, following <denchmark-link:https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/>https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/</denchmark-link> . We use Ambassador to do load balancing and we can open up Kubeflow Central Dashboard UI. However, both Katib (/katib/) and Artifact Store (/metadata/) are "not valid pages" when clicking them from the menu bar; others (pipeline, notebook servers) are fine. All Katib services and pods are running fine. We did not find much useful information in their logs as well. (btw. From <denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/kubeflow/issues/3401>#3401</denchmark-link> , do we need to set up some persistent volumes in this case?) <denchmark-link:https://github.com/cyzhangchenya>@cyzhangchenya</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/jlewi>@jlewi</denchmark-link> I think this has to do with the katib-ui service manifest (<denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/manifests/blob/master/katib-v1alpha2/katib-ui/base/katib-ui-service.yaml>code</denchmark-link> ), it doesn't include ambassador annotations. Easy to fix, shall I create a PR?

That would be very helpful. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/xaniasd>@xaniasd</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/jlewi>@jlewi</denchmark-link>
Otherwise, we do not have a working solution following the official documentation <denchmark-link:https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/>https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/</denchmark-link> . Both Katib (/katib/) and Artifact Store (/metadata/) are "not valid pages" when clicking them from the menu bar; others (pipeline, notebook servers) are fine.

It looks like the Azure instructions are outdated. <denchmark-link:https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/>https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/</denchmark-link>
Kubeflow 0.6 is using ISTIO as its service mesh and gateway. So instead of exposing Ambassador <denchmark-code>kubectl get svc ‚Äìn kubeflow kubectl expose svc ambassador -n kubeflow --type LoadBalancer --name <SVC_NAME> kfctl apply k8s -V </denchmark-code>
You need to expose the ISTIO gateway <denchmark-link:https://istio.io/docs/tasks/traffic-management/ingress/ingress-control/>https://istio.io/docs/tasks/traffic-management/ingress/ingress-control/</denchmark-link>
/cc <denchmark-link:https://github.com/aronchick>@aronchick</denchmark-link>

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/jlewi>@jlewi</denchmark-link> does this mean that setups without istio are not supported any more? FYI: I created a <denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/manifests/pull/300>PR</denchmark-link> solving this issue.

The Azure installation docs at <denchmark-link:https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/>https://www.kubeflow.org/docs/azure/deploy/install-kubeflow/</denchmark-link> are now updated. However, there is always the possibility for the "works on my machine"-syndrome so would be nice to hear if those instructions work for others as well.
We use Ambassador
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/cyzhangchenya>@cyzhangchenya</denchmark-link> If above means that you must use Ambassador, above docs might not cover your needs, because they are based on using Istio.
